head.title: Candidates, Rise to the Global Challenge

hedline.hl1: Candidates, Rise to the Global Challenge

abstract.p: Richard H Lampert letter on Thomas L Friedman's May 12 article holds any presidential election debate on pending technological changes would not be meaningful because presidents do not have power over changes; drawing

block.p: Thomas L. Friedman (column, May 12) astutely points out that challenges related to the digital revolution, biotechnology and financial transactions are global in nature. He suggests, less astutely, that the presidential candidates should hold a debate regarding such problems.

Thomas L. Friedman (column, May 12) astutely points out that challenges related to the digital revolution, biotechnology and financial transactions are global in nature. He suggests, less astutely, that the presidential candidates should hold a debate regarding such problems.

By definition, no head of state -- not the president of the United States, not the prince of Monaco -- will exert any meaningful power over the sorts of problems that Mr. Friedman describes. Creating national laws or regulations regarding these global challenges is akin to those cities that declare themselves ''nuclear-free zones.'' Simply by mentioning the ''I Love You'' virus and alluding to offshore cloning facilities, Mr. Friedman himself makes this point.
The suggested debate might be entertaining, but it would not be meaningful.
